docs.lead_paragraph: International U.N. ENVOY IN AFGHANISTAN ADVOCATES POLITICAL SOLUTION
docs.snippet: International     U.N. ENVOY IN AFGHANISTAN ADVOCATES POLITICAL SOLUTION

docs.lead_paragraph: As Democrats make a final push to adopt health care legislation, House leaders are scrambling for every single vote. Now a House Democrat who opposed the health care legislation in November says it appears to be moving in the right direction, signaling a potential change in his vote.
docs.abstract: Representative Bart Gordon, Democrat of Tennessee, voted against the House health care bill in November but said on Thursday the revised legislation is "moving in a more fiscally responsible direction now."
docs.snippet: Representative Bart Gordon, Democrat of Tennessee, voted against the House health care bill in November but said on Thursday the revised legislation is "moving in a more fiscally responsible direction now."

docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Nathan Deal, Republican of Georgia, who announced his retirement on Monday, said that he would postpone his departure so that he could stay in Congress to vote against the Democrats' big health care legislation.

headline.main: House Republican Postpones Resignation to Vote Against Health Care Bill

docs.abstract: A Georgia Republican said he was persuaded to stay until the House votes on the Democrats' health care legislation.
docs.snippet: A Georgia Republican said he was persuaded to stay until the House votes on the Democrats' health care legislation.

docs.lead_paragraph: 2:26 p.m. | Updated Under questioning from a federal panel overseeing the use of government bailout funds, a senior Treasury official said Thursday that Washington needed to invest in Citigroup to prevent the financial crisis from worsening, The New York Times's Eric Dash reports.
docs.abstract: A senior Treasury official said Thursday that Washington needed to invest in Citigroup in the fall of 2008 to prevent the financial crisis from worsening.
docs.snippet: A senior Treasury official said Thursday that Washington needed to invest in Citigroup in the fall of 2008 to prevent the financial crisis from worsening.

docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Bart Stupak, Democrat of Michigan and a leader among House Democrats who oppose abortion rights, said on Thursday that President Obama needs to be "more flexible" on tightening abortion restrictions in the big health care legislation.

headline.main: Stupak: Abortion Restrictions Must Be Tightened

docs.abstract: Representative Bart Stupak, an opponent of abortion rights, defends reconciliation but says the president must ensure restrictions on public funding for abortion.
docs.snippet: Representative Bart Stupak, an opponent of abortion rights, defends reconciliation but says the president must ensure restrictions on public funding for abortion.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama's full court press on health care is on. The White House just announced that Mr. Obama will meet with a slew of House Democrats today to renew his push for a health care overhaul.

headline.main: Obama Hunts for Votes Among House Democrats

docs.abstract: The president takes the case for a health care overhaul back to House Democrats.
docs.snippet: The president takes the case for a health care overhaul back to House Democrats.

docs.lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.
docs.abstract: Continental will charge for a coach exit seat, members-only sales sites add beauty products and other consumer-focused items from Thursday's Times.
docs.snippet: Continental will charge for a coach exit seat, members-only sales sites add beauty products and other consumer-focused items from Thursday's Times.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama's demand for a nearly immediate up or down vote on health care has Congressional backs against the wall.

headline.main: The Early Word: Up or Down

docs.abstract: President Obama's demand for a nearly immediate up or down vote on health care has Congressional backs against the wall. Meanwhile, there's trouble in New York.
